Posts.Content: Yeah, it's so scary at first and trying to dicipher all the cancer jargon can be too much. 3 weeks is a long time to wait, but be sure to take someone with you to take notes during the meeting. It really helps when you get home and try to remember everything that was discussed. But there are plenty of ladies here who will be glad to answer what questions we can, so ask about whatever is worrying you.
Posts.Title: Grade 3 of 3

Posts.Content: I am taking Arimidex and have osteopeana too. My Onc. is having me take an infusion of zmeta once every 6 months along with regular calcium to strengthen the bones. I too will be curious to see what the next bone scan shows. Dee
Posts.Title: Osteoporosis diagnosis

Posts.Content: Well , your Onc. will have to tell you what your staging means...but clean margins is good news! And no lymph node involvement is also very good news! So chemo and rads followed by 5 years of either Arimidex or Tamoxifin is the pretty standard protocol for most of us.
Posts.Title: Grade 3 of 3

Posts.Content: HER2 negative is also good. Her2 positive is usually more agressive and needs a different treatment protocol. I also am estro/prog+, and my Onc. said this was the slower growing cancer. So, really , you've got 3 good things going for you....clean margins, no node involvement, and HER2 negative.... Dee
Posts.Title: Grade 3 of 3

Posts.Content: I picked up a box at the po today, totally clueless as to what it could be....I opened it and there are all these cute little wrapped presents in it...and then it dawns on me...JUNK SWAP STUFF! YAY! Thanks for all the cute items Teena, I'm not regifting anything.lol! I hope I do as well when I send my box out tomorrow to Susan. Be looking for it! Dee
Posts.Title: Junk Swap Thanks Teena!

Posts.Content: Today one of my high school students came up and was asking me what stage my cancer was at dx(it was stage 2)..she then told me her mother just got dx'd with a stage 4 very aggressive invasive BC 3 weeks ago,already in the lymph nodes etc., and they already have her doing chemo .....I felt so bad for her... she said her mother put off going to the doctor because she was unemployed and didn't have insurance...Yeah,so I get what you mean.... why was I so fortunate to have a curable cancer, while this poor woman with children at home has been hit so hard? Why are small children dying of these agressive cancers while we survive?It's just that genetic timebomb I think......some escape, some don't....So sorry for the loss of Carter...
Posts.Title: Sorry to post such bad news

Posts.Content: Me too. I just finished up the last of my reconstruction surgery, so I'm out of excuses for no exercise and indulgent eating! I gained 20 lbs during the whole year's process and I was already 20 lbs. overweight so I need to go for 40 too. It's my summer goal, so any tips to get me going would be appreciated... Dee
Posts.Title: I need to lose weight and need a support group

Posts.Content: Wow, what a monster...I hope you can find the help you need ...I know we have some lawyers who post regularly and maybe they can help. I can't imagine any court taking your home or forcing you to support this creep. Be strong and never give up the battle.I wish you well. Dee
Posts.Title: metastatic breast cancer and SURVIVING AN ABUSIVE EX-HUSHAND

Posts.Content: Well Taleena Perhaps Mike can also benefit from the info you put together for Bill. It was a very good thing to do. Cheers, Dee
Posts.Title: *****Bill**** This is for you*****B12

Posts.Content: Awwwwww Mike. Sorry someone flagged you. I think for us women the idea of waiting so long for a mammogram is unimaginable.....we just wouldn't do it! We have free mammogram buses coming around all the time for people without resources here in Tennessee as I'm sure they do where you live. There is help out there, so it's hard to imagine just sitting and waiting for weeks just for the initial diagnosis. But you have your reasons, and it's your life, your body. You just have to understand that there is not one woman I know who wouldn't get the test done the next day no matter what the cost. Good luck Dee
Posts.Title: *****Bill**** This is for you*****B12

Posts.Content: My insurance didn't want to pay for a Muga so I had the Echo. The specialist saw a shadow he didn't like and I ended up going back in for a scope procedure where they put a camera down my throat and looked. There was nothing wrong, thank goodness, it was only a shadow. All was well, but it ended up costing the insurance company twice as much as the Muga would have if they'ed approved to start with. My Onc. thought that was hysterical. He loved the pay back. Dee
Posts.Title: echo better than muga scan

Posts.Content: My little yorkie Skeeter is 14 years old....I'll be lost when he leaves me, I know you are sad. Dee
Posts.Title: My Beautiful Angel died

Posts.Content: My little yorkie Skeeter is 14 years old....I'll be lost when he leaves me, I know you are sad. Dee
Posts.Title: My Beautiful Angel died

Posts.Content: Nice hair!
Posts.Title: GRRRRRR updating my pic

Posts.Content: So sorry Debbie. It's a good reminder to all of us with implants that we aren't safe from the beast. Your message will make me more proactive myself. Hope all goes well at Mayo. Dee
Posts.Title: Pink Gloves On - Back in the ring for Round 3!!

Posts.Content: So sorry Debbie. It's a good reminder to all of us with implants that we aren't safe from the beast. Your message will make me more proactive myself. Hope all goes well at Mayo. Dee
Posts.Title: Pink Gloves On - Back in the ring for Round 3!!

Posts.Content: oops
Posts.Title: Pet Scan info

Posts.Content: oops sorry triple post
Posts.Title: Pet Scan info

Posts.Content: Hi! I just had my 2 year mammo and the Onc. followed it up with an MRI to do a double check that all was well.I will have another bone scan in the Fall just to see how the Zometa and Tamoxifen are working.Seems like the 2 year mark is when things start showing up at least according to what I read from the sisters.So maybe that's why they wait til then to do more tests. Dee
Posts.Title: Pet Scan info

Posts.Content: Yea, I think most of us have ports for chemo. It's just easier when you have to get lots of infusions. Then when you're done they'll take it out. Dee
Posts.Title: any thoughts on portacaths?

Posts.Content: Thanks Marilyn I just started on Arimidex and I am already feeling the joint stiffness.Anything that helps!
Posts.Title: Help for AI side effects, maybe...

Posts.Content: Hmmm. I only had one positive node but my margins were't clear after the lumpectomy and my surgeon decided I needed the mastectomy from that and then chemo and rads. If you had clean margins, you may not need the mastectomy. Dee
Posts.Title: triple neg breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hey CatintheHat I will be turning 60 in Nov. just about the time I'll be finised with chemo and radiation...you better believe I'm going to celebrate! I want all my friends around me to share my happiness at having made it through this horrific last few months.We'll go find a great restaurant /bar and let loose. I hope you do the same with your friends. We deserve it. Dee
Posts.Title: Time to Celebrate

Posts.Content: I got a bad one on my upper chest about week four and now I have one under my arm pit.yuk But I only have a couple of treatments left and the Xclair cream they prescribe is good(but expensive) ask for samples... Dee
Posts.Title: radiation,10 treatments down.When is the normal to get burns from it?

Posts.Content: Yeah, the last thing you want to deal with on top of the cancer is a stupid fibroid tumor. I had one before my BC dx eight pounds....yes I said 8 lbs! Talk about looking preggo...I had recently lost 70 lbs and all of a sudden here was this hard thing sticking out of my belly.But they are almost always benign, and the surgery wasn't terrible. Stick to your guns with your daughter now and when she gets through her tweens she'll be ok. Keep us posted on your fibroid....so far I think I'm the champ of ridiculously huge unnoticed tumors.lol.
Posts.Title: finding things a little difficult - acupuncture update

Posts.Content: So sorry Jayne I know this must be terrifying for you. But until you've met with the Onc. or surgeon and find out what kind of cancer{there are several kinds, some more agressive than others),the stage and grade, whether it's ER{estrogen fueled) etc, try not to immagine the worst. It may turn out that you've caught it early, that it's one of the less agressive forms and that you will be just fine. Take someone with you to your appointment to take notes and ask questions. You will need time to digest what you are hearing, and having someone else there helps. I took my best friend with me and she has been my support through the whole ordeal. I worked through part of my chemo and all of my rads. It is doable. Now it is 2 years after my dx and my life is pretty much back to normal. Please know that everyone on here has been where you are now, and most of us are doing well. Ask anything that you are confused about once you have seen your doctor. Someone will know the answer. Dee
Posts.Title: Leukemia now breast cancer

Posts.Content: So sorry Jayne I know this must be terrifying for you. But until you've met with the Onc. or surgeon and find out what kind of cancer{there are several kinds, some more agressive than others),the stage and grade, whether it's ER{estrogen fueled) etc, try not to immagine the worst. It may turn out that you've caught it early, that it's one of the less agressive forms and that you will be just fine. Take someone with you to your appointment to take notes and ask questions. You will need time to digest what you are hearing, and having someone else there helps. I took my best friend with me and she has been my support through the whole ordeal. I worked through part of my chemo and all of my rads. It is doable. Now it is 2 years after my dx and my life is pretty much back to normal. Please know that everyone on here has been where you are now, and most of us are doing well. Ask anything that you are confused about once you have seen your doctor. Someone will know the answer. Dee
Posts.Title: Leukemia now breast cancer

Posts.Content: So very sorry to hear of your loss Skipper
Posts.Title: I Lost My Sister Today

Posts.Content: So very sorry to hear of your loss Skipper
Posts.Title: I Lost My Sister Today

Posts.Content: You're making me laugh out loud again!
Posts.Title: This could be a scam....or not!

Posts.Content: Teresa I gained a good 20 lbs during chemo and I was already 20 lbs overweight so I'm packing a good extra 40lbs myself right now. My plastic surgeon has never said a word about my weight. He did my expander and my reconstruction. I really can't see what difference it would make.The implant is stuck under the muscle with the newly expanded skin stretched over it..I've heard that really thin women have the most trouble because they don't have a lot of skin to expand! I would definitely go to another plastic surgeon...
Posts.Title: my first plastic surgeon visit not good

Posts.Content: You're making me laugh out loud again!
Posts.Title: This could be a scam....or not!

Posts.Content: Hey guys I actually gained 20 ls on chemo cause all I wanted was starchy comfort foods and I gave myself permission to eat whatever I could get down. I'll worry about it later...fiddle dee dee....
Posts.Title: appetite

Posts.Content: I'd go to the Regioal Cancer Center Mike. They will assemble a whole team just for your care and treatment, from diagnosis, to surgery, to chemo, to radiation, and anything else that pops up. My Breast cancer center has been the best! Let us know what you find out my man! Dee
Posts.Title: outside the VA - where do I go from here?

Posts.Content: Hi Surf I havn't even started chemo yet but I already have my fake eyelashes and eyebrows ready...plus wig, hat etc...Has anybody used the eyebrows they sell on the cancer sites? How do they look? Yes I am a tad vain.... Dee
Posts.Title: Eyelashes

Posts.Content: Mine's at the 6 month mark , but it's white and fuzzy and sticks out in all directions...really lovely..lol..I'm going to give it a couple more months and then go for the olor and style....til then the wig stays!
Posts.Title: It's the Hair

Posts.Content: Glad things were ok for you Margo! Now just relax and don't try to do too much and take your antinausea meds.
Posts.Title: My first treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Dale You are not alone in this. We all feel that isolation from people who have not experienced cancer. It is a very exclusive club that you have unfortunately become a member of. But so have all of us on the board. And we are here to help each other through every step of the way. Chemo is the scariest part of the whole trauma for a lot of us. It certainly was for me. To let them shoot poisons into your veins, not knowing what the effect will be on your body, is a crazy thing to have to do. But they are so good at controlling the side effects now that most of us experience very little nausea. I'll have my 4th treatment next week, and I just feel lethagic for a few days. Good luck and let us know how it goes. Dee
Posts.Title: So scared, alone and need to RELAX....HELP

Posts.Content: I drove myself to all my treatments except the first one. And I drove wherever I needed to go after....it will just depend on how you feel, if you experience nausea or not. I had a continual mild nausea, but nothing that would keep me from driving. One side effect can be diarea, so that might make your bus route difficult.I had days where I had to pull into 4 or 5 fast food joints trying to get home.
Posts.Title: Chemo and driving?

Posts.Content: So glad it went ok for you!
Posts.Title: 1st chemo...the worst bit was walking thru the door!

Posts.Content: Hey there I'm a high school teacher and I just told them enough that they knew I'd be out a lot at first. As we've progressed through the semester they have begun to ask more questions about treatments which I dont mind answering. As someone else mentioned, many of them have personal family experience with cancer and it gives them a chance to talk about it and relate their experiences. I never really addressed the wig issue as I started the year with it and it wasn't that different then my normal hair. In a couple more months when I have enough hair back to go wigless, that may be a shock! I think because most of us dont "look" sick, that it's easy for them to forget that we are battling cancer on a day to day basis.
Posts.Title: Any Teachers here?

Posts.Content: Congrats Traci! I had my dance a couple of weeks ago and I've been grinning ever since.. Yipee!
Posts.Title: Hands off, girls -- NED is all mine today!

Posts.Content: Yes. My ONC. has started recommending Claritin for bone pain.
Posts.Title: Tips and tricks for chemo. - would appreciate

Posts.Content: Hey Slurp The claritin works great after the Neulasta shots, which causes your bones to ache. You wouldn't think claritin would help ,but it does. I'll be doing #5 next week and I always have my claritin and my immodium in my purse. Dee
Posts.Title: Tips and tricks for chemo. - would appreciate

Posts.Content: Ok, so the local hospitals are posting BC commercials to promote their various facilites during BC awareness month..and I find so many of them downright offensive! In order to promote their wonderful care...they have women saying " some people say cancer is a "bad thing, but for meeeeeee it has been a blessing"... A "BLESSING"???? Ok maybe the "wonderful" care you recieved, the new appreciation for life, the compassion of friends and family are blessings.....but cancer??? I imagine how people with terminal cases who are fighting for thier lives feel when they hear this garbage and it just makes my blood boil! Ohhh crass comercialism!!!!
Posts.Title: BC Commercials...Ranting!

Posts.Content: This is reprehensible! I can't imagine my doctors being so unresponsive to my concerns! I'd look for a new Doctor.
Posts.Title: I'm another one that needs to vent

Posts.Content: A background check is supposed to look for a criminal record isn't it? I've NEVER had someone ask for my credit history in a job interview...that's none of their business! Ask your local employment agency about that....it sounds like an invasion of privacy to me....I don't think they have the legal right to ask you that...
Posts.Title: Job Interview Questions

Posts.Content: Hey Pink If you're on the every 3 week plan, the 1st week is the worst, but it gets progressively better til by the third week you feel pretty normal..then you get t do it all over again! But you are fortunate to have great friends and family...and it doesn't sound like you have to worry about work...so just dont fight the fatigue...go to bed and rest and now you are 1 down, 5 to go!
Posts.Title: New to discussions and have questions

Posts.Content: One of the hardest things I ever had to do was walk in and sit down in that chemo chair the first time. It is frightening. But once you do it, I promise it really isn't that bad. Look around you at the other ladies chatting, reading, eating, sleeping, during treatment, and you realize nothing terrible is going to happen to you....take your antinausea meds and you will be fine. Good luck! Dee
Posts.Title: First Chemo today

Posts.Content: It has hit us all so hard. I think because we were gearing up to stand beside our sister through her new battle .....it wasn't supposed to end like this...so suddenly and unexpectedly.....I have cried all day...
Posts.Title: I know I am not alone.
